slug: /165
title: "This Week In React #165: StyleX, CSS Hooks, PandaCSS, Tailwind, Redux, Astro, Next.js, Remix, Storybook, React-Native 0.73, State of React-Native, Skia text layouts, Expo EAS..."

segments.source_content: Meta's CSS-in-JS solution is finally open-sourced, after a long wait. It is used on major apps such as Facebook, Instagram and WhatsApp. It is not strictly coupled with React. Atomic CSS will be extracted at build time, and there is a lightweight runtime for concatenating classes. TypeScript support is well-thought-out. The API is minimalist, relying mainly on 2 functions: `create` and `props`. We'll see how this new solution will position itself in an ecosystem that is already fairly competitive with Tailwind, Panda and a few others.

translations.fr: La solution CSS-in-JS de Meta est enfin open-source aprÃ¨s une longue attente. Elle est utilisÃ©e sur des applications majeures comme Facebook, Instagram et WhatsApp. Elle n'est pas strictement couplÃ©e Ã  React. Le CSS atomique est extrait au moment du build, avec un runtime lÃ©ger pour concatÃ©ner les classes. Le support TypeScript est bien pensÃ©. L'API est minimaliste, reposant principalement sur 2 fonctions : `create` et `props`. Reste Ã  voir comment cette nouvelle solution se positionnera dans un Ã©cosystÃ¨me dÃ©jÃ  concurrentiel avec Tailwind, Panda et quelques autres.
translations.en: La solution CSS-in-JS de Meta est enfin open-source aprÃ¨s une longue attente. UtilisÃ©e sur des applications majeures comme Facebook, Instagram et WhatsApp, elle n'est pas strictement couplÃ©e Ã  React. Le CSS atomique est extrait au build, avec un runtime lÃ©ger pour la concatÃ©nation des classes. Le support TypeScript est bien conÃ§u. L'API minimaliste repose principalement sur 2 fonctions : `create` et `props`. Nous verrons comment cette nouvelle solution se positionne dans un Ã©cosystÃ¨me dÃ©jÃ  concurrentiel avec Tailwind, Panda et d'autres.

segments.source_content: CSS library with React bindings, offering a real return to basics via inline styles. In [From CSS madness to CSS Hooks](https://nsaunders.dev/posts/css-madness-to-hooks), the author explains how he uses a variable CSS trick to support missing features such as media-queries, pseudo-selectors and so on.

translations.fr: BibliothÃ¨que CSS avec bindings React, proposant un retour aux fondamentaux via les styles inline. Dans [From CSS madness to CSS Hooks](https://nsaunders.dev/posts/css-madness-to-hooks), l'auteur explique comment il utilise une astuce CSS variable pour supporter des fonctionnalitÃ©s manquantes comme les media-queries, pseudo-sÃ©lecteurs, etc.
translations.en: BibliothÃ¨que CSS avec bindings React, proposant un vÃ©ritable retour aux bases via les styles inline. Dans [Du chaos CSS aux CSS Hooks](https://nsaunders.dev/posts/css-madness-to-hooks), l'auteur explique comment il utilise une astuce CSS variable pour supporter les fonctionnalitÃ©s manquantes comme les media-queries, pseudo-sÃ©lecteurs etc.

segments.source_content: Personally, I've always preferred the DX of inline styles, but in practice this is too limited and doesn't always perform well. It remains to be seen whether this innovation will hold up in practice. Mark Dalgleish (ğŸ¦ [tweet](https://twitter.com/markdalgleish/status/1729399475494608923)) is excited about it. Note Adam Wathan probably wouldn't have created Tailwind if inline styles had better support (ğŸ¦ [tweet](https://twitter.com/adamwathan/status/1732209400641724785)).

translations.fr: Personnellement, j'ai toujours prÃ©fÃ©rÃ© l'expÃ©rience dÃ©veloppeur des styles inline, mais en pratique c'est trop limitÃ© et pas toujours performant. Reste Ã  voir si cette innovation tiendra en pratique. Mark Dalgleish (ğŸ¦ [tweet](https://twitter.com/markdalgleish/status/1729399475494608923)) est enthousiaste. Notez qu'Adam Wathan n'aurait probablement pas crÃ©Ã© Tailwind si les styles inline avaient un meilleur support (ğŸ¦ [tweet](https://twitter.com/adamwathan/status/1732209400641724785)).
translations.en: Personnellement, j'ai toujours prÃ©fÃ©rÃ© la DX des styles inline, mais en pratique c'est trop limitÃ© et pas toujours performant. Reste Ã  voir si cette innovation tiendra. Mark Dalgleish (ğŸ¦ [tweet](https://twitter.com/markdalgleish/status/1729399475494608923)) s'en rÃ©jouit. Notez qu'Adam Wathan n'aurait probablement pas crÃ©Ã© Tailwind si les styles inline avaient un meilleur support (ğŸ¦ [tweet](https://twitter.com/adamwathan/status/1732209400641724785)).

- ğŸ“œ [How does xxx compare to Panda CSS](https://www.astahmer.dev/posts/how-does-xxx-compares-to-panda-css): good presentation of Panda CSS by its maintainer, who also outlines its current limitations. A modern CSS-in-JS solution based on static analysis and compatible with Server Components. There is a light JS runtime, but the atomic CSS remains extracted at build time.
- ğŸ“œ [Tailwind has a scalability problem. How can we solve that?](https://byteofdev.com/posts/scale-tailwindcss/): suggests using `cva` (Class Variance Authority) to make Tailwind code more digestible in a React context.
- ğŸ“œ [Guide to fast websites with Next.js: Tips for maximizing server speeds and minimizing client burden](https://vercel.com/blog/guide-to-fast-websites-with-next-js-tips-for-maximizing-server-speeds): guest post on an agency's Vercel blog explaining the Next.js techniques used to achieve very good performance.
- ğŸ“œ [Fastest Way of Passing State to JavaScript, Re-visited](https://calendar.perfplanet.com/2023/fastest-way-passing-state-javascript-revisited/): SSR-based React/Redux apps need to send the store data to the client-side for hydration. Presents 3 techniques with their performance.
- ğŸ“œ [Keep Your Loader Data Fresh in Remix](https://sergiodxa.com/tutorials/keep-your-loader-data-fresh-in-remix): shows how to call the `useRevalidator` hook when the connection is restored or the tab regains focus.
- ğŸ“œ [Build your own StorybookGPT](https://storybook.js.org/blog/build-your-own-storybook-gpt/): explains how to use AI to generate your stories automatically.

segments.source_content: [Wallaby.js](https://wallabyjs.com/?referrer=ThisWeekInReact1) runs your tests immediately as you type, with runtime values, errors, and code coverage displayed in real-time right next to your code.
